greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array read by antidiagonals, j>=1, k>=1: T(j,k) is the j-th number n such that the symmetric representation of sigma(n) has at least a part with maximum width k.
comment: This is a permutation of the natural numbers.
For more information about the widths of the symmetric representation of sigma see A249351 and A250068.
link: Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
example: The corner of the square array T(j,k) begins:
For j = 1 and k = 2; T(1,2) is the first number n such that the symmetric representation of sigma(n) has a part with maximum width 2 as shown below:
The widths of the symmetric representation of sigma(6) = 12 are [1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1], also the 6th row of triangle A249351.
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Jul 08 2015
